metadata.description: NFL defensive formations, coverages, and blitz packages

4-3.name: 4-3 Base
4-3.description: Traditional base defense with 4 down linemen

3-4.name: 3-4 Base
3-4.description: Versatile defense with 4 linebackers for blitz flexibility

nickel.name: Nickel
nickel.description: Sub package with extra DB for passing situations

big_nickel.name: Big Nickel
big_nickel.description: Hybrid with extra safety instead of corner

cover_0.name: Cover 0
cover_0.description: Pure man coverage with no safety help - all out blitz. This is the defense's most aggressive call, sending extra rushers while every DB plays tight man coverage. High risk, high reward.
what_works: Quick slants and hot routes beat the pressure
Double moves exploit no safety help
Crossing routes create natural picks in traffic
Any broken coverage is a touchdown

cover_1.name: Cover 1 (Man Free)
cover_1.description: Man coverage underneath with a single high safety providing help over the top. The most common man coverage in football. Allows teams to play aggressive man while having a safety net for deep balls.
what_works: Crossing routes force defenders through traffic
Pick/rub plays create separation
Attacking the middle underneath where there's no zone help
Posts can hold the safety and open up other receivers

cover_1_robber.name: Cover 1 Robber
cover_1_robber.description: Cover 1 with a defender (usually LB or SS) 'robbing' underneath routes, reading the QB's eyes. Designed to take away the quick underneath throws that normally beat Cover 1.
what_works: Vertical routes go over the robber
Double moves - robber commits to first route
Taking shots deep since robber vacates deep middle
Flooding one side to move the robber

cover_2.name: Cover 2
cover_2.description: Two deep safeties split the field in half, while corners drop to cover the flats. Creates a 'shell' look with five underneath defenders. Great for defending the sidelines but leaves the deep middle vulnerable.
what_works: The 'hole shot' - deep middle between safeties is wide open
Corner routes split the corner and safety
Smash concept high-lows the corner
Seam routes up the hashes
what_wont_work: Trying to throw over the top outside

cover_2_man.name: Cover 2 Man
cover_2_man.description: Man coverage underneath with two deep safeties providing help. Combines the tight coverage of man with the deep security of two-high. Often used in obvious passing situations.
what_works: Crossing routes create picks just like Cover 1
RB wheel routes vs LBs - huge mismatch
Rub/pick concepts get receivers free
Levels concept with crossers at different depths

tampa_2.name: Tampa 2
tampa_2.description: A Cover 2 variation where the MLB drops deep to cover the middle hole. Made famous by Tony Dungy's Tampa Bay teams. Requires an athletic MLB who can run with receivers.
what_works: Seam routes can still beat the dropping MLB
Corner routes still work - same Cover 2 weakness
Four verticals stresses the MLB
Getting the ball out before MLB gets depth
what_wont_work: Deep middle posts - MLB takes this away
Trying to throw over the middle early
weaknesses: Seams can still work with timing
MLB in space vs athletic TEs
soft_spots: Flats if ball comes out quick

cover_3.name: Cover 3
cover_3.description: The most common zone coverage in football. Three defenders (two corners + FS) each cover a deep third of the field. Four underneath defenders handle short/intermediate routes. Great run support with 8 in the box.
what_works: Four verticals puts 4 receivers vs 3 deep defenders - someone is open
Curl-flat combo high-lows the flat defender
Seams between corner and safety
Flooding one side with 3 receivers vs 2 defenders
what_wont_work: Go routes into the corner's third

cover_3_sky.name: Cover 3 Sky
cover_3_sky.description: Cover 3 variant where the strong safety plays the flat instead of a linebacker, with the free safety in the deep middle. 'Sky' tells the SS to come down. Better vs TEs and strong side runs.
what_works: Attacking the weak side where coverage is softer
Backside posts - FS has whole middle
Weak side seam routes
Flooding away from the SS
what_wont_work: Attacking into the SS in the flat
TE flat routes to the strong side
Expecting easy throws to the strong flat
strengths: SS in flat is more athletic than LB

cover_3_cloud.name: Cover 3 Cloud
cover_3_cloud.description: Cover 3 with the corner dropping to the flat instead of playing deep third. The SS rotates to cover the deep third. 'Cloud' tells the corner to come down. Good for press coverage teams.
what_works: Quick flats - corner is dropping, not sitting
Speed outs before corner settles
Bubble screens with good blocking
Attacking before the corner gets to his spot
what_wont_work: Expecting the corner to be deep

cover_3_match.name: Cover 3 Match (Rip/Liz)
cover_3_match.description: Pattern-matching Cover 3 that starts zone but converts to man based on receiver routes. If #2 goes vertical, defenders 'match' and carry him man-to-man. Handles four verticals better than traditional Cover 3.
what_works: Routes that settle in zones - sit down and find grass
Option routes that change based on coverage
Making defenders wrong with route combinations
Creating confusion with pick routes
what_wont_work: Simple four verticals - they match it
Running verticals and hoping for blown coverage

cover_4.name: Cover 4 (Quarters)
cover_4.description: Four defenders each cover a deep quarter of the field. The safest coverage against deep balls - almost impossible to throw over the top. The tradeoff is soft underneath coverage.
what_works: Underneath routes are wide open - take what they give you
Curls, hitches, flats all available
Smash concept attacks the corner
Dink and dunk down the field

cover_4_palms.name: Cover 4 Palms (Poach)
cover_4_palms.description: A quarters variation where safeties read the #2 receiver. If #2 goes out, safety 'poaches' or jumps the out route. If #2 goes vertical, safety carries him deep. Creates turnovers vs predictable passing games.
what_works: Smash can still work - corner route beats the corner
Corner routes attack the soft spot
Making safeties wrong with route combinations
7 routes (corner routes)
what_wont_work: Out routes from #2 - safety is sitting on it
soft_spots: Anything that bends back to sideline deep

cover_6.name: Cover 6
cover_6.description: Split coverage - Cover 4 (quarters) to the field/wide side, Cover 2 to the boundary/short side. Defenses use this to handle trips formations or take away specific concepts to each side.
what_works: Attack the Cover 2 side with corner routes and hole shots
Identify which side is Cover 2 pre-snap
Flood the Cover 2 side
Smash to boundary
what_wont_work: Going to the wrong side with the wrong concept

cover_2_trap.name: Cover 2 Trap
cover_2_trap.description: Looks exactly like Cover 2 pre-snap, but one safety bails to rob routes, baiting the QB into a bad throw. A 'trap' coverage designed to create turnovers by disguising as standard Cover 2.
what_works: Throw opposite the trapping safety
If you identify the trap, the other side is wide open
Double posts can expose which safety traps
Run the ball - they're playing pass
soft_spots: The side without the trap safety

edge_blitz.name: Edge/DB Blitz
edge_blitz.description: Corner or safety blitzing off edge

overload_blitz.name: Overload Blitz
overload_blitz.description: Overload one side with more rushers than blockers

double_a_gap.name: Double A-Gap Mug
double_a_gap.description: Two LBs in A-gaps pre-snap, may or may not blitz

green_dog.name: Green Dog
green_dog.description: LB blitzes if his man (RB) stays in to block
